subject: math
title: Introduction to Algebra
description: Learn the basics of algebra including variables and expressions
content:
Introduction to Algebra

Algebra is a branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and the rules for manipulating those symbols. It's a unifying thread of almost all of mathematics and is essential in everyday problem solving.

What is Algebra?

Algebra is the study of mathematical symbols and the rules for manipulating these symbols. The symbols represent quantities and relationships between them.

Key Concepts

  • Variables: Symbols (usually letters) that represent unknown values
  • Constants: Fixed numerical values
  • Expressions: Combinations of variables, constants, and operations
  • Equations: Statements showing two expressions are equal

Example: Solving Simple Equations

If 2x + 5 = 13, what is x?

Solution:

  1. 2x + 5 = 13
  2. 2x = 13 - 5
  3. 2x = 8
  4. x = 4

Practice Problems

  1. Solve: x + 7 = 12
  2. Solve: 3x = 21
  3. Solve: 2x - 4 = 6

subject: math
title: Quadratic Equations
description: Master quadratic equations and their solutions
content:
Quadratic Equations

Quadratic equations are polynomial equations of the second degree. They have the general form: ax¬≤ + bx + c = 0

Forms of Quadratic Equations

  • Standard Form: ax¬≤ + bx + c = 0
  • Vertex Form: a(x - h)¬≤ + k = 0
  • Factored Form: a(x - r)(x - s) = 0

Methods to Solve

  1. Factoring
  2. Completing the square
  3. Quadratic formula: x = (-b ¬± ‚àö(b¬≤ - 4ac)) / 2a

Example

Solve: x¬≤ - 5x + 6 = 0

Using factoring: (x - 2)(x - 3) = 0

Solutions: x = 2 or x = 3

subject: math
title: Trigonometry Basics
description: Introduction to trigonometric ratios and identities
content:
Trigonometry Basics

Trigonometry is the study of relationships between angles and sides of triangles.

Primary Trigonometric Ratios

  • Sine (sin): Opposite / Hypotenuse
  • Cosine (cos): Adjacent / Hypotenuse
  • Tangent (tan): Opposite / Adjacent

Special Angles

Angle0¬∞30¬∞45¬∞60¬∞90¬∞
sin01/2‚àö2/2‚àö3/21
cos1‚àö3/2‚àö2/21/20

Applications

Trigonometry is used in:

  • Navigation and surveying
  • Engineering and construction
  • Physics and astronomy
  • Music and sound waves

subject: science
title: Physics Fundamentals
description: Understanding the basic laws and concepts of physics
content:
Physics Fundamentals

Physics is the natural science that studies matter, motion, and forces. It helps us understand how the universe works.

Major Branches of Physics

  • Mechanics: Study of motion and forces
  • Thermodynamics: Study of heat and energy
  • Waves & Optics: Study of light and sound
  • Electromagnetism: Study of electricity and magnetism
  • Modern Physics: Study of atoms and relativity

Fundamental Concepts

  • Force: A push or pull on an object (F = ma)
  • Energy: The ability to do work
  • Motion: Change in position over time
  • Momentum: Mass times velocity (p = mv)

Newton's Laws of Motion

  1. An object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a force
  2. F = ma (Force equals mass times acceleration)
  3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction

subject: science
title: Chemical Reactions
description: Learn about chemical reactions and chemical equations
content:
Chemical Reactions

A chemical reaction is a process that leads to the transformation of one set of chemical substances to another.

Types of Chemical Reactions

  • Synthesis: A + B ‚Üí AB
  • Decomposition: AB ‚Üí A + B
  • Single Replacement: A + BC ‚Üí AC + B
  • Double Replacement: AB + CD ‚Üí AD + CB
  • Combustion: Substance + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí CO‚ÇÇ + H‚ÇÇO

Chemical Equations

A chemical equation shows the reactants and products of a chemical reaction.

Example: 2H‚ÇÇ + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 2H‚ÇÇO

This means: 2 molecules of hydrogen gas react with 1 molecule of oxygen gas to produce 2 molecules of water.

Key Concepts

  • Reactants: Substances that participate in the reaction (left side)
  • Products: Substances produced by the reaction (right side)
  • Catalyst: A substance that speeds up a reaction without being consumed
  • Activation Energy: Energy needed for a reaction to begin

subject: science
title: Biology Basics
description: Explore the fundamentals of living organisms
content:
Biology Basics

Biology is the natural science that studies life and living organisms, including their structure, function, and evolution.

Levels of Organization

  1. Atoms and Molecules
  2. Cells (the basic unit of life)
  3. Tissues
  4. Organs
  5. Organ Systems
  6. Organisms
  7. Populations
  8. Communities
  9. Ecosystems
  10. The Biosphere

Cell Theory

  • All living things are made of cells
  • The cell is the basic unit of life
  • All cells come from pre-existing cells

Major Branches

  • Botany: Study of plants
  • Zoology: Study of animals
  • Genetics: Study of heredity and genes
  • Ecology: Study of organisms and their environment
  • Evolution: Study of change in organisms over time

Characteristics of Living Things

  1. Organization and structure
  2. Metabolism
  3. Growth and development
  4. Reproduction
  5. Response to environment
  6. Homeostasis
  7. Evolution
